Pri Microsoftu preizkušajo 4-dnevni delovnik

07 Nov 2019, 08:29


Microsoft se poigrava z idejo, da bi zaposlenim omogočil 4-dnevni delovnik.

V Microsoftovi izpostavi na Japonskem so dejali, da se je prodaja povečala za skoraj 40 %, potem ko so zaposlenim testno zmanjšali delovni teden na 4 dni. Kljub krajšemu delovniku je zaposlenim pripadala celotna plača.
Pisarne so v avgustu 2019 zaprli vsak petek, redno zaposleno osebje je dobilo "poseben dopust", ki je bil plačan. Sestanke so omejili na največ 30 minut, spodbujali pa so tudi spletne diskusije kot alternativo osebnim stikom. Japonski delavci imajo sicer enega najdaljših delovnikov na svetu.
Raziskava iz leta 2017 je pokazala, da ima skorajda četrtina vseh podjetij na Japonskem zaposlene, ki pridelajo na mesec več kot 80 večinoma neplačanih nadur. Microsoftov poskus so zato delavci lepo sprejeli. Tekom mesečnega testnega obdobja je poraba elektrike padla za 23 %, porabili pa so tudi 59 % manj papirja za tiskanje. Pri tehnološkem gigantu še poudarjajo, da pripravljajo širšo strategijo preživljanja delovnega časa. Vključevala naj bi tudi načrt za spodbujanje zaposlenih, kako “bolj pametno počivati”.
V nasprotju z Microsoftom je Jack Ma, soustanovitelj Alibabe, že pred časom uvedel 12-urni delovnik. Aprila letos ga je opisal kot “vzorec 996”, to je delovnik od ponedeljka do sobote od 9.00 do 21.00, kar naj bi bilo za delavce “blagoslov”.
Poročilo, ki ga je v Veliki Britaniji naročila laburistična stranka, navaja, da bi bil štiridnevni delovni teden z omejenimi urami "nerealen". "Čeprav so nekateri prisiljeni delati manj ur, kot si želijo, dela večina ljudi dejansko dlje," še piše v poročilu. Številni delavci se znajdejo v situaciji, da morajo enako količino dela stlačiti v krjaši delovni čas, kar je lahko precej stresno.

At Microsoft, they are testing a 4-day working day

07 Nov 2019, 08:29


Microsoft is toying with the idea of giving employees a 4-day working day.

A Microsoft office in Japan said sales had increased by almost 40% after reducing the test week to 4 days. Despite the shorter working hours, the employees were paid the full salary.
Offices closed every Friday in August 2019, full-time staff received a "special leave" that was paid. They limited meetings to a maximum of 30 minutes and encouraged online discussions as an alternative to personal contacts. Japanese workers have one of the longest workers in the world.
A 2017 survey found that nearly a quarter of all businesses in Japan have employees who produce more than 80 mostly unpaid overtime a month. The Microsoft experiment was therefore well received by the workers. During the monthly test period, electricity consumption dropped by 23% and 59% less printing paper was consumed. The tech giant also stresses that they are preparing a broader strategy for working hours. It should also include a plan to encourage employees to "rest smarter".
Unlike Microsoft, Jack Ma, co-founder of Alibaba, introduced a 12-hour workbook some time ago. In April this year, he described it as a "sample 996", which is Monday to Saturday from 9am to 9pm, which is supposed to be a blessing for workers.
A report commissioned by the Labor Party in the UK states that a four-day working week with limited hours would be "unrealistic". "Although some are forced to work fewer hours than they want, most people actually work longer hours," the report said. Many workers find themselves having to pay the same amount of work in part-time, which can be quite stressful.
